sentences.sentence: I was born in the year 1632, in the city of York, of a good family.
My father was a foreigner from Bremen, who settled first at Hull and became a successful merchant( 商人 ).
After retiring from his trade, he moved to York, where he married my mother.
Her family name was Robinson, a very good family name in that country, and after whom I was called Robinson Kreutznaer (Kreutzauer being my father’s name).
But, by the usual corruption( 语言变体 ) of words in England, we are now called Crusoe, which is the name my companions always called me.
I had two older brothers, one of whom was a colonel( 上校 ) in an English foot patrol( 步行巡逻队 ) unit in Flanders, and was killed in battle near Dunkirk against the Spaniards( 西班牙人 ).
What happened to my second brother I never knew, any more than my father or mother knew what became of( ...情况如何了 ) me.
Being the third son of the family, and not trained in any trade( 职业 ), my head began to be filled very early with wandering thoughts.
My father wanted me to study law, but I would be satisfied with( 满足于 ) nothing but going to sea. My attraction to this led me strongly against the will of my father.
There seemed to be something fateful( 宿命的 ) in that tendency of my nature, leading directly to the life of suffering which was to come to me.
My father, a wise and serious man, gave me excellent advice.
He urged( 劝说 ) me strongly not to play the young man, nor to bring upon myself unnecessary suffering.
He told me it was either desperate( 破釜沉舟的 ) men, or ambitious( 野心勃勃的 ) ones, who went abroad on adventures, to succeed by taking chances( 投机 ) and make themselves famous.
These things were all either too far above me or too far below me, for mine was the middle state—one of what might be called the middle class( 中层 ).
He had found, by long experience, that this was the state most suited to human happiness.
He tried to help me by giving me a start in the type of life which he had just been recommending to me.
In a word, he would do very kind things for me, if I would stay and settle at home as he directed. He did not want to bring troubles upon me by giving me any encouragement to go away.

He told me I had my elder brother for an example, whose young desires had led him to go into the army, where he was killed. He went so far as to say( 甚至说 ) to me that if I did take this foolish step, God would not bless me.
He warned me that I would one day remember having ignored( 忽视 ) his advice, when there might be no one to help me.
This last part of his speech was truly far-sighted( 有远见的 ), though I suppose my father did not know it himself.
I saw the tears run down his face, especially when he spoke of my brother who was killed. When he spoke of my having no one to help me, he was so moved that he stopped speaking.
He told me his heart was so full that he could say no more to me.
I was sincerely( 由衷地 ) moved by( 被…感动 ) this speech. Indeed, who could have remained unaffected?
I decided not to think of going abroad any more, but to settle at home according to( 按照 ) my father’s desire.
But, alas( 唉 )! After a few days I changed my mind, and a few weeks later I decided to run away from( 逃避 ) him.
However, I took my mother aside( 把...叫到一旁 ) at a time when I thought her a little more pleasant than she normally was, and told her about my plan to see the world.
I wanted her to ask my father to let me go on one voyage abroad, and if I came home again and did not like it, I would go no more.
This caused my mother great distress( 忧虑 ).
She told me it would be useless to speak to my father about it. She wondered how I could think of any such thing after the conversation I had had with my father.
In short, if I would ruin myself, there was no help for me. She for her part( 就某人而言 ) would take no part in my destruction.
It was not until almost a year after this that I broke loose( 摆脱束缚 ).
I happened to( 碰巧 ) be in Hull when one of my companions, who was about to sail to London in his father’s ship, invited me to go with them.
I did not ask my father or mother, or even tell them of it, but left them to hear of it as they might.
On the 1st of September, 1651, I boarded a ship bound( 前往...的 ) for London.
Never has any young adventurer’s bad luck, I believe, begun sooner or continued longer than mine.
The ship was no sooner out of the harbor, than the wind began to blow, and the sea to rise in a most frightful manner.
As I had never been at sea before, I was unspeakably( 极度严重地 ) sick in body, and terrified( 非常害怕的 ) in mind. I began now seriously to reflect upon what I had done.

All the good advice of my parents, my father’s tears and my mother’s pleas( 恳求 ), came now fresh into my mind. My conscience( 良心 ) criticized( 批评 ) me for ignoring( 忽视 ) their advice, and for failing in my duty to God and my father.
All this while the storm increased, and the sea went very high. Though it was nothing like what I have seen many times since, nor what I saw a few days after, it was enough to affect me then.
I expected( 觉得 ) every wave would swallow us up( 吞没 ), and every time the ship went down into a hollow( 凹陷处 ) between waves, I thought we would never rise again.
In this distress( 苦难 ), I made many promises that if God would spare my life, I would go directly home to my father, and never set foot( 登上 ) on a ship again.
Now I saw plainly how right my father was about the middle way of life. He had lived comfortably all his life, and never had been exposed( 使暴露于 ) to storms at sea or troubles on shore.
These wise thoughts continued while the storm lasted, but the next day the wind and the sea were calmer, and I began to get used to them.
Towards night the weather cleared up( （天气）转晴 ), and a lovely fine evening followed. The sun went down perfectly clear, and rose the same the next morning.
The sight of a smooth sea, with the sun shining upon it, was the most delightful sight that I ever saw.
